7.title: Newswatch: AI-eager doctors, AI-reticent buyers, AI cost worriers, more
7.text: In medicine’s next chapter, AI literacy will separate physician leaders from peer followers.

7.title: For patients with complex care needs, AI is helpful—but the human touch is irreplaceable
7.text: Primary care providers are excited about the promise AI holds to help them help patients living with multiple chronic conditions. However, they believe these patients will continue to need the human connection they get from their PCPs.

7.title: That’s no mere hospital—it’s a ‘complex adaptive system.’ Use GenAI accordingly.
7.text: From the perspective of management science, healthcare is a complex adaptive system marked by intricate feedback loops and overlapping interdependencies. As such, the sector demands caution by those introducing large-language AI into its tangled webs.

7.title: 7 pointers for AI-driven quality control in medicine
7.text: By automating repetitive tasks and ensuring consistent “QC,” well-deployed AI not only unburdens healthcare professionals but also sets new standards for efficiency and reliability in medical practice.

7.title: Healthcare AI newswatch: Devices of unknown generalizability, promises of uncertain keepability, more
7.text: Overpromising AI capabilities to hospital stakeholders—now there’s a mistake healthcare AI enthusiasts have been known to make.

7.title: Industry watchers call healthcare AI a ‘double-edged sword’ that ‘cannot function in isolation’
7.text: Healthcare may finally have struck a healthy balance between AI hype and AI reality, according to a report from impartial observers who are also, indirectly at least, healthcare AI stakeholders.

7.title: Russian researcher strategizes on collaboration with China over healthcare AI
7.text: Have you ever wondered what China and Russia would talk about if they were to discuss AI in healthcare? It turns out they do just that—and a newly published academic paper straight out of the Russian Federation offers a glimpse into the dialogue.

7.title: 5 attributes every AI system will soon need to make hay in healthcare
7.text: “Dr. AI” will never replace a single human physician. But its many makers’ relentless pursuit of perfect performance all but guarantees the technology a prominent role in healthcare.

7.title: Primary care is primed for AI. But is AI aligned with primary care?
7.text: Fewer than one-third of primary care clinicians have a say in selecting the AI products their institutions expect them to fold into their clinical workflows. That’s a problem.

7.title: AI newswatch: Nurses want in, transcriptionists on the way out, blockchain going up, more
7.text: If doctors are the heart of the hospital, nurses are surely the soul. And if that’s so, today’s AI has to be something like a nutritional supplement for the brains of the operation.

7.title: AI can be health equity’s best friend—or one of its worst frenemies
7.text: AI can hurt or help the cause of advancing equality of resources, services and outcomes in healthcare. If it’s to do more helping than hurting, the technology must permeate primary care—and do so with certain goals and guidelines.

7.title: If present trends continue, the healthcare AI revolution may leave 56 million Americans behind
7.text: Research into the design and development of AI models for rural healthcare isn’t hard to come by. However, that’s about as far as most of the investigations go.

7.title: Healthcare AI today: Nurses called to AI action, Big Beautiful Law, of mice and AI, more
7.text: If nurses fail to lead the way toward safe and responsible use of healthcare AI, the profession may lose its voice on emerging technologies.

7.title: Healthcare AI newswatch: Does healthcare AI need DEI? | Insider AI risk | 2025 Turing Prize | more
7.text: If U.S. healthcare is to help advance responsible and ethical AI for all communities, it very much needs to continue prioritizing DEI initiatives.

7.title: Healthcare AI newswatch: Bill Gates detractors, structured medical timelines, helpful China tariffs, more
7.text: Bill Gates wasn’t just wrong to suggest AI will make physicians unnecessary. He was reckless.

7.title: Research review: Patients have understandably mixed feelings about AI in healthcare
7.text: A new review of the relevant scientific literature suggests many if not most patients are aware that healthcare AI’s emerging benefits exist side-by-side with its persistent uncertainties.

7.title: Healthcare AI newswatch: RFK Jr. for animal-saving AI, Dr. Oz’s big plans for AI at CMS, more
7.text: The Department of Health and Human Services is looking to replace lab animals with AI models. Even more bullish on AI is the new boss at the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services.

7.title: Healthcare AI today: Bipartisan AI policy guidance, AI claims denials, LLM brain rot, more
7.text: Federal lawmakers have a fresh resource to keep them up on healthcare AI that falls outside of formal FDA oversight. It comes in the form of a new report from the nonprofit Bipartisan Policy Center.

7.title: AI has come a long way in healthcare, still has a long way to go: Research recap
7.text: As AI continues its march through healthcare organizations around the world, the notion that it will replace the sector’s human workers fades but does not disappear.

7.title: Healthcare AI newswatch: Fail-fast AI skunk works, writerly doctors avoiding AI scribes, more
7.text: Is trial and error any way for a sprawling health system to roll out AI? Duke Health’s chief medical information officer believes so.

7.title: AI and QI—a partnership made for healthcare
7.text: Within healthcare, artificial intelligence and quality improvement have some things in common.

7.title: Healthcare AI now: New code of conduct, iffy FDA oversight, Dr. AI for the wealthy, more
7.text: On the technical and ethical planes, the National Academy of Medicine’s fresh guidance may represent the best way yet to ensure alignment of healthcare AI stakeholders.

7.title: Healthcare AI today: JCAHO–CHAI teamwork, what patients everywhere want, when to restrain AI, more
7.text: The Joint Commission is partnering with the Coalition for Health AI to scale AI accountability. The project will supply more than 80% of U.S. provider orgs with gameplans, toolkits and overall guidance.

7.title: AI in the ICU: ‘Unique challenges requiring specialized oversight’
7.text: The AI revolution in healthcare is less about technological advancement than change management vis-à-vis human relations. This may be nowhere more true than in critical care.

7.title: Healthcare AI newswatch: FDA’s ‘rush’ to the AI altar, AI and Medicare Advantage, OpenAI benchmarks healthcare AI
7.text: For some, the FDA is moving too fast in its drive to adopt generative AI agency-wide.

7.title: Global market researchers: ‘Build a culture that uses healthcare AI to uplift human potential’
7.text: To maximize returns on AI investments, healthcare organizations should align AI initiatives with core competencies. The effort should focus on optimizing experiences for workforces as well as patients.

7.title: Healthcare AI newswatch: UnitedHealth hearts AI, agentic AI again, healthcare AI dependency, more
7.text: Give healthcare workers AI to do their jobs and you might make them AI-dependent. Give them AI anyway?

7.title: Will AI help or hurt the cause of healthcare equality?
7.text: AI has a long way to go before it meaningfully closes disparities in healthcare access and delivery. In fact, even when aimed at that goal, the technology can backfire.

7.title: AI vs. medication errors, Health Tech Investment Act preps, employment apocalypse fears, more
7.text: Remember when comprehensive checklists and human vigilance were going to end medical error? That hasn’t happened yet. AI might be able to help.

7.title: Epic, Microsoft lead the AI vendor charge into healthcare: KLAS
7.text: Many if not most hospitals and other provider organizations take a decided interest in what their peer institutions are doing with AI. A major motivator for the keen curiosity is gauging how well one is keeping up with the Joneses. So to speak.

7.title: Why do AI-savvy consumers harbor skepticism toward medical AI?
7.text: Patients who frequently use AI tend to readily trust AI-assisted diagnoses made by their physicians. Counterintuitively, however, those who would rank themselves among the very best-informed about AI tend to mistrust such diagnoses.

7.title: How to let AI simplify the complexities of care (rather than allowing it to do the opposite)
7.text: Healthcare AI can add considerable value to patient care practices, but it can also “just add noise to an already complex system.”

7.title: First, do no AI: How not to help the world’s struggling healthcare systems
7.text: An international team of researchers is calling on healthcare AI proponents to be more mindful of the technology’s unsuitability across much of the developing world.

7.title: The future of hospital logistics is with AI
7.text: In hospital settings, the success of AI adoption hinges on how well implementation leaders balance technological innovation in departmental silos with operational nimbleness across the enterprise. In a term, the latter refers to hospital logistics.

7.title: 5 ways AI can help a hospital’s discharge department
7.text: Among the myriad processes to which AI could be meaningfully applied in healthcare, perhaps few are more easily overlooked than discharging patients from the hospital.

3.title: Healthcare AI newswatch: Payer AI regulation please, pharmacy AI, nurses v. AI redux
3.text: Unionized nurses: ‘AI overrides our expertise and degrades the quality of care.’

3.title: Healthcare AI newsmakers: Chief AI & transformation officers, AI Rorschach testers, citizens united for responsible healthcare AI, more
3.text: Less alarm fatigue in overworked pediatric nurses means more time for imperiled pediatric patients.

3.title: Healthcare AI newswatch: Surgical symphonies, integrated intelligence, generalist AI, more
3.text: The surgeon is only one member of a team in the OR.

3.title: The future of AI in nursing is already here yet still on the way
3.text: Is AI changing the profession of nursing—or are nurses changing AI?

6.title: Patients size up GenAI for mental healthcare one way, for physical healthcare another
6.text: Healthcare consumers considering the use of large language AI for mental healthcare are apt to shy away from the technology if they feel it might put their privacy at risk.

6.title: Newswatch: AI researchers weigh in, AI humanizes healthcare, ‘the worst AI will ever be,’ more
6.text: Contrary to popular misgivings, AI may be improving the human touch in healthcare.

6.title: Newswatch: FDA’s AI plan ‘ahead of schedule and under budget,’ AI fears vs. comforts, AI ROI, more
6.text: We’re either teetering at the edge of AI overlordship—or just working with new tech tools that do the same old computer-y things we’ve always done. So which is it?

6.title: Healthcare AI today: AI stink-eye, disrespect for AI-toting docs, super-eager clinical adopters, more
6.text: Gen Xers and their elders tend to believe AI will do more harm than good. More than half of American adults 50 and older place themselves in that somewhat cynical category.

6.title: A symbiosis observed: How AI is refining the savviness of the e-patient
6.text: The shoulders on which healthcare AI stands span from the advent of the World Wide Web, email and electronic medical records to the ubiquity of smartphones, patient portals, telehealth and personal health wearables.

6.title: Healthcare AI newswatch: Apple’s AI Doctor, AI’s expectant medical specialties, AI-watching teens, more
6.text: Apple’s AI Doctor had better be one good virtual physician.

6.title: AI elevates telemedicine and protects its data too
6.text: AI can improve the quality of remotely delivered care while simultaneously defending privacy and security for the telehealth patient.

6.title: Healthcare AI today: Mayo book, fraud busting, ‘shapeless monsters,’ more
6.text: Some AI researchers have taken to calling certain LLMs ‘Shoggoths.’ Be afraid. Be very afraid.

6.title: HIMSS survey report: Beware insider threats to cybersecurity involving AI
6.text: Almost one in three healthcare organizations allow their people to use AI without formal restrictions.

6.title: AI newswatch: Lifecyle AI oversight, data matters, AI vs. animals, more
6.text: AI may finally end the paper chase caused by prior authorization. Or it may worsen it.

6.title: Ambient scribe technology all the rage despite uneven interest and ‘still imperfect’ performance
6.text: As applications of AI spread rapidly across healthcare, ambient scribes are poised to become one of the fastest technology adoptions in the history of the sector.

6.title: When health accessories grow up, they want to be wearable AI
6.text: Wearable health gadgets equipped with AI present myriad opportunities and challenges to healthcare consumers and the healthcare professionals who diagnose, treat and track them.

6.title: To tell or not to tell: Do patients really need to know who—or what—writes their doctor’s notes?
6.text: When blinded as to authorship, healthcare consumers slightly prefer medical messages composed by generative AI to those written by human clinicians.

6.title: Healthcare AI newswatch: FDA’s AI gambit, FDA’s blind spot, everybody’s agentic AI, more
6.text: The FDA is getting AI-aggressive about speeding up device reviews. Its plan is to unleash generative AI on tedious and repetitive tasks.

6.title: Research brief: Cybersecurity threats inherent to AI-aided remote patient monitoring
6.text: Leveraging the upsides of RPM with AI demands human attention to numerous challenges. Primary among these are privacy and cybersecurity risks, researchers report.

6.title: 3 points to ponder before tapping AI for mental healthcare
6.text: Earlier this year, patients treated by an AI chatbot for some common mental health challenges got better. This was significant because the patients were part of the first randomized and controlled trial for this type of AI intervention.

6.title: 5 ways AI can help make healthcare more affordable for everyone
6.text: The people who can least afford healthcare are often among those who need healthcare the most.

6.title: Machine learning vs. bodily pain: 5 points of promise and challenge
6.text: We have seen the future of pain management, and it is in automated assessments aided by AI.

6.title: Vocal AI can sub for professionals to give and grade elderly cognitive exams
6.text: When paired with willing older adults, talking AI can administer and assess preliminary dementia tests in much the same way—and with similar effectiveness—as human specialists.

6.title: How generative AI for healthcare is similar to—and different from—its conventional older cousin
6.text: The National Academy of Medicine considers some pertinent ins and outs of GenAI.

4.title: Healthcare AI newswatch: Ambient AI costs, healthcare AI holdouts, an 86-year-old AI innovator, more
4.text: Meet an 86-year-old IT entrepreneur who recently beefed up his AI skills in a challenging postgraduate program.

4.title: Healthcare AI newswatch: Great expectations for GenAI, disaster-ready AI, Dr. Oz on payer AI, more
4.text: Investors are betting on generative AI to solve costly provider workflow inefficiencies. So are provider executives.

4.title: Newswatch: AI for Medicare folk, AI uncertainty at the FDA, generative ghosts, more
4.text: AI is making patient financial advisors of hospital administrators who used to work in revenue cycle management.

4.title: Healthcare AI newswatch: MAHA’s AI stumble, OpenAI’s healthcare offensive, Mayo’s AI startup support, more
4.text: Mayo Clinic is looking to give promising medtech startups a seriously running start. Toward that end, the august institution has launched the new Mayo Venture Partner program.

4.title: GenAI adopters tentative now but confident soon: Survey
4.text: GenAI initiatives are complex and—in some cases—costly. “As such, the main rationale for pursuing them needs to be business growth, not workforce reductions.”

4.title: Healthcare AI today: HL7 Int’l opens AI office, Justice Dept. uses AI, epidemiologist harbors AI skepticism, more
4.text: HL7 International is open for AI business. The interoperability organization announced the launch of its new AI office July 8.

4.title: 5 things to know about AI-toting healthcare ‘unicorns’
4.text: Why do investors equate these companies with beautiful, mythical beasts? Because startups with such dazzling attributes are—or long were—rarely seen.

0.title: Healthcare AI newswatch: Silent AI threats, overeager clinical AI, trustworthy AI therapists, more
0.text: Some AI decision-support models have a proclivity for recommending aggressive care pathways. And doing so on the basis of patient demographics, not medical necessity.

0.title: Next-generation AI agents are headed for healthcare. What will they do once they get here?
0.text: Healthcare AI agents can be classified as one of four models. In increasing order of autonomy and clinical integration, these are: foundation, assistant, partner and pioneer.

0.title: Healthcare AI newswatch: Regulatory sparring partners, AI nutrition labels, agentic AI basics, more
0.text: Medical device companies navigating regulatory pathways should know: Large language models are not reliable guides.

0.title: When healthcare AI meets the medical humanities
0.text: A primary aim of medical humanities as a field today is teaching medical students how to harmonize technological innovations with care models such that patients are treated as whole persons: They have not just bodies but also minds, relationships—and lives.

1.title: Healthcare AI newswatch: AI-armed patients vs. big medical bills, Trump-era healthcare AI, patient safety anxieties, more
1.text: It’s no surprise Trump Administration II is taking a laissez-faire stance toward AI regulation. After all, the winning candidate campaigned pretty hard on scaling back all regulation.

1.title: Healthcare AI today: Trump’s calculated risks, healthcare’s sluggish revolution, simple AI math, more
1.text: In his drive to keep China from sprinting ahead of the U.S. in the AI arms race, President Trump may be willing to cut some risky corners.

1.title: Healthcare AI newswatch: Trump-era AI regs, AI sign language, AI dentistry, more
1.text: The Trump administration will probably play to type when it comes to regulating AI.

1.title: Healthcare AI today: Pittsburgh’s bonanza, Bay area’s superstars, Dr. Google’s followers, more
1.text: The numbers from Pittsburgh are staggering. And they’re all about blasting American-made AI into the stratosphere, if not to Infinity and beyond.

1.title: AI newswatch: OpenAI goes to the UAE, patients get cyberchondria, more
1.text: Like remoras hitching a ride on a shark, private businesses are capitalizing on President Trump’s AI-aggressive trip to the Middle East.

1.title: AI newswatch: American AI in the United Arab Emirates, healthcare AI investment, med schools embrace AI, more
1.text: Here’s a big thing to watch for in the wake of the President’s flashy Middle East tour: the AI “acceleration partnership” between the U.S. and the United Arab Emirates.

1.title: Healthcare AI today: Senate arguments, aging infrastructure, ‘elastic’ jobs, more
1.text: States’ rights or federal power? Senate Republicans are of two minds on AI regulation in the One Big Beautiful Bill.

1.title: Newswatch: Trump’s AI extraversion, FDA’s first CAIO, healthcare AI’s true value, more
1.text: Where a cautious President Biden wanted to confine American AI know-how to America, a freewheeling President Trump wants to turn it loose—at least to select friends and allies.

1.title: Healthcare AI newswatch: California AI hoping, the jagged AI frontier, agents bumping off bots, more
1.text: California has moved assertively to legislate guardrails around AI in healthcare. Will other states follow?

1.title: Healthcare AI today: Trump’s American AI offensive, healthcare’s lack of regulatory cohesion, chatbots’ silence, more
1.text: President Donald Trump has crystallized his No. 1 priority for artificial intelligence. Unshockingly, it’s “winning the AI race.”

1.title: What federal regulators can learn from the states about AI oversight
1.text: If the Trump administration continues taking a laissez-faire stance toward AI—including AI used in healthcare—why not let the states go it alone on regulating the technology?

2.title: Healthcare AI today: Dangerous LLMs, self-training AI—and is AI good for what ails healthcare?
2.text: If an individual is at all susceptible to mental unwellness, overuse of a talkative LLM could push him or her over the edge. Maybe literally.

2.title: Healthcare AI today: Microsoft’s supersmart medical AI, patients talking street to AI, LLMs don’t really care, more
2.text: Patients who put some personality into their symptom descriptions may flummox large language models—to unfortunate effect.

5.title: Patient portal messages can train AI to support personalized care in endocrinology (and beyond)
5.text: For the study, researchers had five diabetes specialists judge precision AI tools developed from a large, longitudinal dataset of patients’ individually expressed needs.

5.title: Researchers identify ‘universal determinants of AI acceptance’ among healthcare workers
5.text: What attributes tend to nudge clinicians toward accepting AI into their work lives? Several, of course—but the most broadly determinative can be trimmed to just two.

5.title: Healthcare AI today: Aggressive AI spenders, backend AI in healthcare, life-saving AI, more
5.text: The U.S. is one of 23 countries that consider workforce AI training and education only a medium priority. Indeed, our homeland has a less detailed plan than 13 other nations.
